issue_name: Staining and possible mildew or mold formation in attic
issue_description: Inspection of attic revealed some staining and possible mildew or mold formation on the roof sheathing in particular above the main floor bathroom and at the western section of the attic.
issue_summary: Staining and microbial growth occurs for two reasons: a roof leak or condensation.
additional_information: At this time, the staining has not yet lead to any structural damage. It is recommended to improve venting by adding baffles to the soffit areas and also by ensuring the bathroom vent line exhausts to the exterior.
issue_images: Staining and possible mildew or mold formation in attic

issue_name: Front entry dead bolt not operational
issue_description: The strike to the front entry dead bolt is not properly aligned and dead bolt is currently not operational.
issue_summary: Adjust strike as needed to correct.
issue_images: Front entry dead bolt not operational

issue_description: Patch / repair / seal all holes / openings, cracks wider than 1mm in stucco to help prevent moisture, insect, or vermin penetration.
issue_summary: For instance: Keep all exposed wood surfaces, including facia, soffits, gable ends, well-painted to protect against weathering and deterioration.

issue_name: Concrete stairs to front entry lack hand rail
issue_description: The concrete stairs to the front entry need to have a hand rail installed for safety and convenience.
issue_summary: Any hairline cracks in concrete are usually due to shrinkage during the curing process of the concrete.
additional_information: Bigger cracks may be due to some settling and they should be patched and sealed if cracks become more than 3 mm wide to help prevent further deterioration due to moisture and freeze / thaw cycles.
issue_images: Concrete stairs to front entry lack hand rail

issue_description: The hand rail to the sun deck is wobbly and lacks integrity.
issue_summary: Replace hand rail with spindled hand rail for safety and convenience and to protect children from falling off the stairs sideways.

issue_name: Exterior electrical outlets not GFCI protected
issue_description: One or more exterior electrical outlets were found to be not ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI) protected at the time of inspection.
issue_summary: Although GFCI protection may not have been required at the time the home was built, for safety reasons and according to current electrical standards, it is recommended that all exterior electrical receptacles be provided with GFCI protection in good working order to avoid potential electrocution hazards.
additional_information: This can be achieved relatively inexpensively by: 1. Replacing an individual standard receptacle with a GFCI receptacle. 2. Replacing the electrical circuit receptacle located closest to the overcurrent protection device (usually a breaker) with a GFCI receptacle. 3. Replacing the breaker currently protecting the electrical circuit that contains the receptacles of concern with a GFCI breaker.
issue_images: Exterior electrical outlets not GFCI protected

issue_name: Signs of overheating in electrical panel
issue_description: Signs of overheating was noted at a wire near the neutral bar within the main electrical panel, with blackening, melting of wire apparent.
issue_summary: This is a safety issue and a potential fire hazard.
additional_information: It is recommended to have the issue assessed and corrected by a licensed electrician as soon as possible.
issue_images: Signs of overheating in electrical panel

issue_description: A transformer was found inside the main electrical panel.
additional_information: Transformers should be installed outside the electrical panel as per electrical regulations. Correct as needed by a licensed electrician.

issue_description: The toilet isolation valve is leaking steadily. Water has been getting under the floor and is leaking into the basement.
issue_summary: Signs of moisture were observed at the exterior wall near this bathroom and it is suspected that water due to the leaky toilet valve is finding its way into the wall.
additional_information: It is recommended to repair or replace the leaky toilet valve as soon as possible to stop the water leak. Affected areas should be allowed to dry out. Wall should be opened up and assessed for water damage and microbial growth (potential health issue). Remedy as needed and allow wall interior and structure to dry out before re-finishing.

issue_name: Wobbly guard rail between living room and stairway
issue_description: The guard rail / pony wall between the living room and the stairway shows movement and lacks integrity.
issue_images: Wobbly guard rail between living room and stairway

issue_name: Missing hand rail on stairway from entry level to main floor
issue_description: The stairway from entry level to main floor is missing a hand rail.
issue_images: Missing hand rail on stairway from entry level to main floor
